38857415.review:
This is by far my least favourite game from Nickervision. Doesn't make it bad.

If you're not familiar with that developer, gist of those games is: arcade-like, very simple and quick. Well done and fun. Rest of the review will just be complaining, so go get the game (or better yet, grab Orbt XL which is better). It comes from a place of love though - I like the game, but see how much better it could be and it bothers me.

Some of the issues here were also present in BitBlaster XL, but weren't as important, as BitBlaster felt "less endless". It felt like a game that one could be eventually done with and fine with that. This is a bit like super hexagon (or Orbt XL), meaning you will want to replay it a lot more.

Control: there's something wrong with how the controls work. Pressing buttons while transferring between nodes affects your speed, which is somewhat not intuitive in some scenarios (eg. when you are going right, but want to go up soon if you press up before hitting the node you'll slow down. If you press left, you somehow won't).

Simplicity: It's just not very simple, the concept feels either forced or not fleshed out enough. Games like this work, because they have very simple rules. Think super hexagon. Move right/left and don't hit stuff. This one has aspects that took me 1h of play to discover. Granted, this is because it's fast paced and you tend to not pay attention - it's still rather simple.

Content: this game ends too soon. I get the strategy behind this: it's a $.5 game that makes everyone happy. But I want something that will push me to actually get good with it. Be it achievements or unlocks. After 1h of play you have to motivate yourself. This is very much true for all Nickervision games and I see that it's a viable strategy - everyone gets a nice feeling of completing the game and it's hard to justify a negative score for something that cheap. And I'm still recommending it, cause yeah, the price is right and the game is fun. It just could be so much more.

Progression: This is the same issue as Bit Blaster XL. You just get better stuff. Once you unlock the next thing, you won't ever have a reason to go back. I can't stop myself from feeling like this was intentional to serve the part of the audience that maybe isn't that great at games but they want all the achievements nevertheless. You grinded enough, you get the best player character, best is better than what you've been using, better high score, yay progression. I think that's a bit patronizing to gamers and super hard games like super hexagon made big bucks to prove my point. I'd rather see skins, like in Orbt XL.

Overall I feel like the concept isn't all it could be. The game is still good. I think the pricing is very sane (some indie companies would sell a game like this for a lot more - I feel like Nicks sale quantities prove them wrong). I like the sound and the visuals. I love that it works flawlessly on linux (well, the leaderboards don't work but who cares).

36669582.review:
It was a pleasant surprise to play Nickervison Studios previous arcade-style games and find something so entertaining for such a small price.  Diamo XL steps up as their next title falling right in line with the arcade design that I enjoyed so much before, but this time, it may be missing a little of the magic that made Bit Blaster XL and Orbt XL so enjoyable. 

[h1]A diamond in the rough[/h1]

Diamo XL's core premise is essentially to trace the lines of the diamond shape on screen with a gamepad (or keyboard) controlled cursor.  Once you cover all of the lines, you'll be awarded five base points which can be multiplied by a modifier that increases as you continue moving the cursor.  The obstacles are a series of red squares that come hurdling in from all sides to collide with your cursor and end the run.  As you progress, additional enemies appear that do things like temporarily destroy a line in the shape or make a corner inaccessible.  You increase your potential score by maintaining your movement, but too much movement can have you colliding with obstacles much more frequently and ending your run.

One thing that Diamo does very similar to its predecessors is limit player control.  Bit Blaster had it so you could only turn your ship without controlling thrust. Orbt only let you raise or lower the orbit of your cursor while you maintained your movement in orbit. In Diamo, once you've committed to moving down a line to a corner, you can't stop – you can only increase your speed by pushing the button for that direction.  This is actually where I find my biggest issue with the game.  The problem is that you're working primarily with a 'diamond' shape, though the center is filled with a perpendicular crossing.  When using a controller, it's often difficult to use the d-pad to move on the diagonal lines.  It's possible to use “up” to go diagonal and upward to the right or left depending on which side you're on, but logically you try to press the d-pad diagonally which can often register as a press either to the left or up.  This could potentially be resolved by just using a keyboard to dissuade yourself from even having access to a “diagonal,” but I just like I can react faster using a gamepad.  

[h1]Third time isn't always a charm...[/h1]

I can't really say that Diamo XL is bad, but I can say that it doesn't really live up to its predecessors on a number of levels.  Even beyond the control issue, it just doesn't seem quite as fun as Bit Blaster or as engaging as Orbt.  I'm not sure what exactly is missing from the experience, but I can say that when I do lose a run, I am nowhere near as compelled to restart and try again.  However, in general, it's a solid game for its minuscule price, and certainly one worth recommending as a time killer.  I'm sure a future sale could easily take this down to 50 cents and grabbing all three titles in the “Arcade Bundle” is still definitely something I suggest doing.  I just hope that whatever Nickervision has planned for the future has more of what made the their first two titles such enjoyable games.


If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

*edited after playing again*

The game is well polished with achievements,  unlockables and all but I just don't have fun playing.

Nothing major, but I found a couple of gameplay issues:
- The speed system is simple: fast if a key is being pressed, slow otherwise. Yet it's not intuitive: if you're going towards an enemy and want to go back (you can't go back in the middle of a line, but it's a reflex to hit the key to go backwards), you end up moving faster towards the enemy.

36156421.review:
I completed all achievements in less than an hour and i am in the top 50 best score world wide. I also am a big fan of Nickervision and i have all their games (3 at the moment lol).

If you dont have internet or like me, your city suffered a power outtage that cut your internet for 3 days, this game is for you. Lot of fun and pretty challenging, it makes you wish for an online version cause this game has the potential to be a crazy multiplayer game. You just have to move around with a D-Pad, joystick, arrows, or whatever you like and complete diamonds (sets of 4 triangles) to get points. Avoid obstacles and dont stop moving to trigger a score multiplier.

Music is also a 9/10, an improvement to the previous release from this dev (Orbit XL) and UI & playability is also pretty simple and straight forward. 

Overall, i would advise you to buy this on a discount. Although 1$ is cheap, you can always get it cheaper. I got mine at 71 cents. I just wish it would have a multiplayer feature, maybe for the next game :p

9/10

36054011.review: Diamo XL is a nifty little arcade game about filling up a diamond by zooming over lines and scooting past enemies. The game rewards the player with more points for always being in motion, though patience is also rewarding as it allows you to, um, not die. Out of all three of the Nickervision games currently on Steam, Diamo's my favorite. It has a very pleasing minimalistic feel to it, from the graphics to the gameplay. I also like its mechanics that can sometimes tease the player into ruining their run because of greed, and even then it's still easy to pick right back up again. If you've got some spare change in your Steam wallet, go and give Diamo XL a try.

36049419.review:
Diamo XL is yet another fun game from nickervision, definitely worth it


==========


I've been looking forward to this game the moment the images used in the description of the steam store page got uploaded on the dev's account, now the question is: was it worth waiting for?

Positive:
+ the games starts simple and gets progressively harder
+ the main game is really easy to understand, leaving the entire focus game up to you mastering it, which is exactly what this game was striving for

Negative:
- There is multiple players to choose from however, there's absolutely no reaosn to use any of them once you get the player that gets unlocked when you reach 15 000 points, it's just plain better (also the ennemy that gets unlocked when you die at exactly 42 points is worse than the player you start with)
- in addition, the icons used to describe the player stats aren't the most descriptive, mainly the hitbox size icon


So all in all, this is just a great little game for people looking for a game about chasing scores



Rating:
8.5/10

35887504.review:
Once again, Nickervision has impressed me with his new game, Diamo XL. 

The game is simple enough - move along the lines until you have completed the diamond to score points, avoiding the red diamonds of death which are flying towards you. Simple but addictive.It's a great game to play whenever you want a few minutes break from work or study.

As usual, the soundtrack is fantastic - it really reflects the action of the game, starting off slow but building up in speed and complexity as the game continues. It's my favourite thing about it.

Most of the achievements are relatively easy to get, which is good since you'll only be playing this game in short bursts. But there are still 2 or 3 that will be a challenge for those who want to get more out of the game.

At the small $1 pricetag, Diamo XL is hard to turn down - you'll get hours of fun from the loose change left in your steam wallet. Highly recommended.

35856695.review:
Diamo XL is an amazing creation by Nickervision Studios that has kept me enticed for the short period of time that I have owned it, and I presume that it will continue to do so for many more hours to come.

Essentially, Diamo XL is a game in which you try to create the outline of a diamond, moving your ball along the path from line to line. Once you have traced all the outlines you will get more points which are, points. No description needed because I assume that everyone knows what a point is. After you have been moving for a bit, you’ll notice the amount of points you get exponentially increases. This is dependant on the multiplier. You earn a higher multiplier by constantly moving around the diamond and staying alive. 

There are achievements, and I speculate the developers will soon add Trading Cards to the game as they did with Orbt.XL and BitBlaster.XL. Either way, the game is very enjoyable. When you hear the words “arcade’style” or “simplistic” you might think of a boring 2d shooter game just like all the other ones out there. But Diamo XL is so much more than “the other games.” It provides a ton of fun, encourages short gaming sessions yet many of those short gaming sessions [to me. It might be different for you.] and the achievements are difficult to get, meaning that you will spend a decent amount of time before you have achieved everything.

The gameplay reminds me of something from a retro arcade in the 1990’s. Something that just keeps you entertained no matter how many times you play. It’s not like a campaign game that will fade in interest over time, it’s something that you will continue to click on months, maybe even years, from now when you’re looking for something to do.

Video review and gameplay coming soon on my youtube channel, which you can find on my profile in the “videos section”. If you’re unsure about purchasing the game, make sure you check them out when I have the time for editing!

I'd say the simplicity makes it more immediately accessible compared to Orbt XL (visible lines & less variability in what you're avoiding, instead of orbits & trajectories with many types of incoming threat).

It's 63p. 79p if the sale's over. All of his games are worth your time. 

Just get the Arcade Bundle, and stop worrying about whether your rig can cope with the next installment of WolfenCOD Vice City at 240fps.

35831449.review:
From the creator of bit blaster XL comes another game with a similar feel, but another 
style of gameplay. While bit blaster focused on shooters of yester-year in the arcades, 
this focuses on a more original idea.  You are drawing lines to form a diamond while dodging enemies and raising your score. The game still feels like an arcade machine as you try 
and get a high score by drawing a pattern and destroying enemies. At first it seems too 
simple as you move around and collect points. But as you keep playing and getting your 
score higher and keep your multiplier up you get sucked in. Enemies also evolve a bit and
destroy certain paths and block cross roads(temporaraly). Keeping your speed up without 
dying is challenging and addicting. 

The graphics and sound are minimalistic and don't draw you in, but this isn't a bad thing 
as I felt it allowed you to focus on the gameplay. The controls are fine, any mistake you make will be your fault as things get chaotic and you make a mistake in a panic. There are unlockable characters with different stats and sizes to vary things up a bit, though this does bring me to my one critsism. Unlocking characters are cool but the gameplay really could use more stages (or patterens so to speak). There is only one and yes this game is cheap, but thats how much I enjoyed it. Having more would be really sweet and give the game more meat. But again this game is cheap so i'm not gonna criticize this too much. But I do hope the developer expands on this game. It was a nice suprise and like "bit blaster" it's fun, addictive, and nails the feel of being back in the arcades of the 90's.

35830030.review:
Do yourself a fovor. 

Scroll back up a bit, and buy "Arcade Bundle - Nickervision Studios Bundle". 

[spoiler]go down a bit for an actual review[/spoiler]




















Ok now, on to the review of this game.

Diamo XL is a very simple game. That's not a bad thing. That's actually a GOOD thing.

In this game, you move a square around a diamond with two intersecting lines going through the middle to form four right triangles. Once you start moving from a point, you cannot stop until you get to the next point. The only thing you can do is slow down by letting go of whatever button you're using to move or speed up by holding it down. Red shapes will come from the sides of the screen and go towards the diamond shape that you can move on. As you may have guessed, these are enemies and touching one will kill you. When you move across a line, it turns blue. If you turn all of the lines blue, you get a relatively large score bonus. Running into small blue circles will also give you points. You can earn a score multiplier of up to 5x by constantly being in motion. Stopping for more than about a second will cause your score multyiplier to quickly go down.

That's everything I can think of on how to play. That's it. Just a few sentences. A medium-sized paragraph sums up the entiree game.

But trust me. The game's fun. Simple isn't bad. In Pac-Man, you moved a yellow circle around a maze and got small white dots. That game is still played today. 

Recommended, strongly recommended, and that's all I have to say.

35793999.review:
玩了3小时，终于做完了全成就，其实应该是2天，因为这两天玩游戏的时间基本都在玩这游戏，主要是最后两个成就不怎么好做，好了，接下来谈谈我对这游戏的感受。
一如另外两款游戏，简单但精致，游戏玩法类似一笔画，但有所不同，玩家控制一个小点，走遍整个路径完成图形，同时躲避周围的障碍，但要注意的是小点一旦移动，在到达下一个点之前是不能改变方向或者停止的，但可以加速。与一笔画不同的是，走过的路径可以重复走，而且和另两款游戏有所不同的是，玩家控制的小点可以停在原地，游戏的节奏由玩家自己决定。

因为游戏没有中文，虽然不影响游玩，但是一些基础细节需要摸索，这里便为不懂的人说下：
1、在重新进入游戏后，会有选择不同类型的方块（后面统称为方块）可选择，但需要玩家在玩游戏时解锁，具体解锁自行看要求或者慢慢玩等解锁。说下方块头顶上两个属性所代表的意义。第一个氮气标志（比较像）代表你在控制方块加速时的速度，这个不必多说；第二个标志可能有人看不懂，这里说一下，那个反向箭头标志代表方块的大小，同时！这个也间接代表方块的初始速度，也就是你按一下方向键方块的速度，数值越大方块越大，初始速度也越慢。
2、整个图形分为五个点，，同时被分为四个小区域，当组成区域的三条线全部走过，该区域便会有5秒左右的组合时间（暂且这么称呼），见区域内淡蓝色面积变化。
3、障碍只讲特殊作用的，目前我的分数最高只打到629分，不清楚后面有没有其他特殊障碍，讲下我见过的。一类是破坏障碍，它会暂时破坏外圈的一条线，并且与其相连的线要重走一遍，还没见过同时出现2个或以上的破坏障碍；另一类是寄生障碍，它会暂时使外圈的一个点不能去，但不会破坏走过的线，持续时间3秒左右，分为两种，一种只寄生，另一种在寄生时间结束会向寄生点的左右方向发射两个障碍。

然后讲下我摸索的的一些小技巧：
1、挑选方块，方块的大小和速度有着各自的优势。尺寸小速度快的方块更容易完成图形，而且加速移动时更容易躲开障碍；尺寸大速度慢的方块在正常移动的时候相比小方块一头撞到障碍上，可以更好的躲过障碍。怎么选择看每个人自己的需求，个人推荐侧重速度，因为后面障碍极多并且密集，小方块能更好躲过。
2、成就里比较难完成的便是最后两个，累积15000分可以慢慢玩，另一个以42分过一轮，可能有人搞不懂，我为了这个成就花了一小时。在进行游戏的时候，上方的分数旁有一个combo条，其实很好理解，比如如果是3倍，你吃到一个1分的能量点，那你得到的分数便是1*3分。所以这个成就最好在刚开局就做，这样分数看的清楚，不要急着完成图形（完成图形的加分不算在要求里），等能量点出现。理解了这个，这个成就便是最好做的了。

最后还是期待下作者的新作品，然后我要继续去做打飞机那个游戏的成就了，那个是真的难。。。
如有不足，请多包涵。

35784043.review:
Honest review: More fun than Bit Blaster XL, less fun than Orbt XL.

A challenging, fast-paced game of drawing diamonds that turns into a game of mostly avoiding stuff.

The biggest drawback is that once you press a direction, you can't reverse - I'm sure this is intentional rather than an oversight, however it does mean you'll sometimes see your loss coming and be powerless to stop it. 

The top and bottom corners can sometimes have enemies approaching from above or below that have little warning, and late-game enemies begin to involve area denial, which sometimes comes close to feeling like you have nowhere to escape to.

Despite all that, I had fun managing to get a good high score, and completed the achievements in just under two hours. Recommended.

35765500.review:
Like all of Nickervision's games, Diamo XL is a fantastic and addictive time waster.

In this game, you attempt to traverse the lines between the points of a diamond and its constituent triangles, while dodging projectiles which destroy you on contact. You gain points for covering every line that makes up the diamond, near misses, and touching dots which also randomly appear and move along said lines.

The challenge comes from the progressively more varied and numerous projectiles, some of which can even destroy lines. The longer you last, the higher your multiplier, and the faster you move (or so it seems,) the higher your score.

It's an incredibly easy to learn yet difficult to master game, equal parts imminently casual, and maddeningly challenging as you go on. You can unlock different player icons by achieving specific objectives, much like Orbt XL.

My sole criticism of the game is that movement in the desired direction seems to be most easily achieved by using up, down, left, and right, despite four of the lines being diagonal. Moreover, since (on a controller at least,) those directions are most precisely hit using the D-pad versus the analog stick, I do at times find that the direction I press is not the direction I move in, frequently leading to premature failures. This is a minor criticism however, since a) it could simply be my D-Pad, and b) keyboard controls are also available.

All in all, fun, affordable game.

35764425.review:
EDITED REVIEW: So I wrote what I thought was a "hilarious" review about this game, but didn't mention how the game was thoughtfully, so I will write a sincere review of this game.

Diamo XL is a simplistic arcade puzzle game where you have to draw lines within a 4 sided diamond shape, with 4 rectangles in it. Dodging the red geometric asteroids creates the challenge to get a high score without getting hit at all.

The aesthetic of these games, if you have played the developer's games beforehand, is that there are no frills, simple as it is with unlockable avatars with faster/slower speed and low/high multipliers. A great and cheap game that cost the same price as a soda.

35698019.review:
Similar to Nickervision's previous titles, Bit Blaster XL and Orbt XL, Diamo XL is another easy-to-learn simple score-attack arcade game. Complete with an optional tutorial and an immediate restart option upon game over, the game's pace and flow is steady and consistent. 

The gameplay is simple; using the four directional inputs (up, down, left, right), you guide your character to a point on the diamond grid. Once you start moving, you can't stop until you reach the next node, so timing is needed to avoid the enemy projectiles. The goal of the game is to traverse all 8 paths of the diamond grid to score points, then repeat the process indefinitely while avoiding red enemy projectiles that hover over the map. After game over, you're presented with numerous detailed statistics about your playthrough, such as amount of time spent idle, number of diamonds completed, close calls, etc. as well as the option to tweet your score, compare your score to others on the global leaderboard, try again or return to the main menu.

The game rewards you with a higher score multiplier the longer you go without moving, and there's a cooldown for said combo multiplier as to not make the gameplay feel too rushed or hectic. Similar to Bit Blaster and Orbt, the difficulty starts out easy then scales to be more difficult the higher your score gets; more enemy projectiles on screen, new enemies that disable sections of the grid for a short period of time, etc. The game also rewards you with different "characters" to choose from, and they're unlocked simply by playing the game; the more you play, the more points you earn, and each character's unlocking criterion (i.e. Earn X points in total) is shown in the character select screen.

I played this game with my Xbox360 Afterglow USB controller and had no issues, and there's an option to disable controller rumble in the options. If the catchy music track isn't to your liking or you're getting tired of it, you can also disable it (and sound effects) in the options menu and just play your own music in the background instead. 

In conclusion, Diamo XL plays exactly how it's presented. The content, gameplay and replayability make Diamo XL worth its low price, especially if it goes on sale.

35696921.review:
Diamo XL is an amazing game; its simplistic, fun and progressively challenging. If you have ever played a game by Nickervision Stuidos before then you will understand what I mean.

The game gets harder as you progress and though each playthrough is the same, the enemies are randomised entirely. The game offers little towards progression, you only unlock new characters after getting a certain score - personally I don't like this system and would prefer something like in Bit Blaster XL where my points accumulate as a currency and from there I can buy new characters.

Pros:
- Fun
- Challenging
- SImplistic
- Awesome Soundtrack
- Great Visuals
- Great Concept

Cons:
- Same shape over and over
- No real objective; there's no reason to play other than to get a higherscore

Potential Ways to Improve:
- Change the character unlock system, please let me accumulate my points to buy a new character :)
- Online leaderboard would be a nice addition.
- New Levels - each with a new shape.
- Multiplayer; probably a HUGE ask but being able to do a survival challenge between friends - whether local play or not, that would be amazing!

Addictive, simple and most importantly fun.

With a soundtrack that doesn't feel repetitive because you're too focused on where to move next. This is like old arcade games where you are compelled to keep dumping in quarters to retry and get that better score because you KNOW you can do it.

As always with this developer, for a dollar you get quite a bit out of it. A list of achievements, not all will be easy to obtain, so there's something in it for the achievement hunter type. With a public leaderboard you also have the ability to compete with your friends or random people. 

TL;DR:
Like an arcade game but doesn't cost you a thousand dollars in quarters.
Fun, fast and easy to get into, difficult to master.
Unlockable characters to keep it fresh and give you goals. 
Achievements are not all easy.
It's only a dollar.

The second u load this up and that beat starts you feel pumped to try ur best in this minimilistic but suprisingly challenging game.

In case people arent sure what you do, I have pulled this quote from the store page

"Survive the constant onslaught of obstacles by moving your character to all five zones within the Diamond. Collect points before the enemies smash them and keep moving to keep your multiplier high. Fill in the four triangles to complete the Diamond and get bonus points. Simply holding any of the four directional buttons allows your player to move around the Diamonds zones at a high rate of speed, if you just tap the direction your player will move at half the speed."

39251446.review:
As an easy to grasp arcade game, Diamo XL does an excellent job at providing challenge, fun and the right kind of frustration where only the player is to blame. 

The gameplay concept seems simple at first, as it doesn't emphasise fast reflexes and instead relies on observation skills. In practice though, that's what unexpectedly trips up the player, because every mistake is either an assessment fault or rash twitch reaction. There's more than enough time to estimate the speed and timing of the obstacles and sometimes, especially at higher scores, it's even advisable to stay put for half a second or more. Waiting at the right time is tougher than it seems if the game pushes a constant movement flow and punishes stalling.

There's only one minor annoyance where obstacles layered on top of each other are hard to distinguish and keep track of. It's still doable but potentially unfair within a perfect storm sequence. Also, with the mouse brain I have, every now and then it's confusing to quickly determine the right direction with the arrow keys on a diamond shape.

With polished visuals and a good use of tempo in the music, Diamo XL is an unequivocally recommendable arcade gem.

Heads up though: My Xbox 360 wired controller did not work as intended with this game. It could be a user error but I didn't dig deeper and just switched to keyboard controls.

39215044.review:
Einfaches Spielprinzip, einfache Steuerung. Sehr herausfordernd.

Großartiges kleines Arcade-Game, in dem es sehr auf Geschick, Schnelligkeit, Koordination und Übersicht ankommt.
Fesselt einen sofort, Lerneffekt setzt fast ebenso schnell ein und so ist das Spiel echt ein netter Zeitvertreib.

39193032.review: Another simple, but addictive, game from Nickervision.  It is similar to the old arcade game Qix in that you have to fill in spaces while avoiding being hit by the enemies.  You are, however, limited only being able to move around the lines that already exist.  Perfect game to waste a little time while you're in a multiplayer queue or when you just want something that doesn't require a lot of time or that has more complex gameplay.

I prefer this game overal to Orbit as the player character you unlock dont just change the look but actually mix up the game play for the better like in BitBlaster. 
Overall a great little steam title to pick up for a little relaxing break.
8/10

40904285.review:
Геймплей очень прост - нужно нарисовать 4 треугольника, чтобы дали очки. Но в этом будут мешать красные шары, которые летят через поле. Сложность нарастает по мере набора очков. Есть модификатор, который накапливается до 5-ти - увеличивает получение очков, который уменьшается, если стоять на месте. Т.е. активная игра (без простоя) приносит больше очков, но особо опасные моменты можно переждать, а потом снова набрать модификатор.

На мой взляд не хватает штрафов на общий результат за бездействие, чтобы было больше стимула играть активнее.

Хорошая игра, в которой можно скоротать время, пока ждешь рейтинговый матч в Gremlins, Inc.

40851093.review: 2.6小时通关，攻略已经有大神在测评里写了。因为最后一个成就是积攒15000分，所以达到这个成就其他成就基本都已经过了，再不行就用最后一个解锁的方块刷吧。游戏心态很重要，手残的我在400分成就之前上300分都很偶然，但我刷到400分的那把获得了全成就的时候忽然释然，然后就刷到了500多分。。所以当做休闲游戏享受也是一个很好的选择。

40831651.review: Don't think just buy it. Not just this game, buy the bundle.

40811811.review:
I really enjoyed this dev's games and actually went as far as to 100% the other two.

This game has control problems. You can hold the direction you're going in to go faster, but the game seems to randomise what direction you have to hold to go faster.

As an example: you could be moving down. So you hold down to go faster. The game ignores you. You then hold right, and amazingly, the game responds to the incorrect input.

As a result, this is not a good game. The very controls themselves are broken.

The soundtrack is OK but repetitive, and the game itself is not anywhere near as fun as the other two.

2/10, I regret this purchase.
